column4: Qualcomm to pay $975 mln to resolve China antitrust dispute

column4: Breakingviews: China pulls its punches with Qualcomm settlement
column5: HONG KONG (Reuters Breakingviews) - China has held back with its Qualcomm settlement. The country's antitrust watchdogs hit the U.S. chipmaker with a $975 million fine on Feb. 9 and forced it to lower patent fees. That's helpful for local smartphone makers that rely on Qualcomm's third and fourth generation mobile technology. Yet the resolution stopped short of explicitly curbing the tech giant's dominance in the country. Big as China is  it can't yet afford to shut out foreign technology.

column4: Exclusive: GM's Barra faces roadblocks in rebuilding Cadillac brand
column5: DETROIT General Motors Co Chief Executive Mary Barra's strategy of rebuilding the Cadillac brand has run into twin roadblocks: the carmaker can't persuade enough American sedan buyers to switch from foreign competitors such as BMW or Mercedes  and it can't make enough of its Escalade SUVs to satisfy domestic demand.

column4: Genworth Financial loss exceeds estimates

column4: Goldman ex-programmer files new lawsuit to recoup legal fees

column5: NEW YORK  Feb 10 U.S. oil services giant Halliburton said it expects to cut between 6.5 percent to 8 percent of its global workforce due to the "challenging market environment" caused by low oil prices.

column5: LONDON  Feb 10 The head of Lloyds Banking Group  has called for greater competition in providing banking services to small firms  including making it easier to switch accounts.

column4: BAE Systems  TAE to handle F-35 maintenance in Australia
